title: 111_hr4100
content: The "Jumpstarting Our Business Sector Act of 2009" is a new law that provides capital gains tax relief by excluding certain dividends and long-term capital gains temporarily. The "Jumpstarting Our Business Sector Act of 2009" excludes certain dividends and long-term capital gains from gross income for taxable years 2009 and 2010. Amendments are made to the tax code to clarify the exclusion of dividends under section 139D. Amendment to the tax code includes a new item after section 139C. Amendment to the tax code includes temporary exclusion of certain dividends and long-term capital gains, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. Additionally, there is a temporary reduction of employment taxes. Temporary reduction in employment taxes is proposed for a period of 2 years after the enactment of the subsection, with adjustments to tax rates for both employees and self-employed individuals. The amendment reduces employment taxes for employees and self-employed individuals, with different effective dates for each group. The amendment reduces corporate marginal income tax rates. The amendment reduces corporate marginal income tax rates for taxable years beginning in 2009 and 2010, with a 15% tax on income up to $50,000 and a 25% tax on income exceeding $75,000. Personal service corporations will have a 25% tax rate. The amendment includes temporary rate reductions for 2009 and 2010, with a 5% tax rate substituted for 10% and a 10% tax rate on taxable income over certain brackets. Additionally, unobligated stimulus funds are rescinded. "Unobligated balances of discretionary appropriations from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 are rescinded by this Act."
